node.title: Protesters march over ‘greenwashing.’
node.alt: Activists protesting “greenwashing” near the COP26 climate summit in Glasgow on Wednesday.
node.description: As the focus of the Glasgow summit turns to funding, protesters call for greater accountability for companies’ climate promises.
node.content: ["As delegates inside the COP26 conference hall in Glasgow heard promises of new private-sector funding for climate change, protesters marched in the city on Wednesday in opposition to \u201cgreenwashing\u201d \u2014 when companies claim to be protecting the environment while continuing to harm it.", "More than 100 protesters, holding signs that read \u201cAct now!\u201d and \u201cStop Funding Fossil Fuels,\u201d gathered outside a shopping mall to demand that companies take more substantial steps.", "\u201cFor us, there\u2019s very little hope,\u201d said Akke Houtsoma, 20, an administrative worker who had traveled from the Netherlands to attend protests outside the climate conference. \u201cI feel the most anxiety not about my future, but for the people right now who are suffering.\u201d", "A focus of the climate conference on Wednesday has been on how to pay for a global shift to cleaner energy sources. Even as a group of the world\u2019s biggest investors, banks and insurers vowed to commit their more than $130 trillion in assets to pursuing climate goals, protesters were doubtful that the promises would be fulfilled.", "\u201cThe promises coming out are quite good, but they are still just promises,\u201d said Marilyn Spurr, 74, a retired high school teacher from Devon, England, who is a member of Extinction Rebellion, a British-based activist group. \u201cIf they step up to the mark, good for them, but so far we haven\u2019t seen a lot of it.\u201d", "Activists said there needed to be stronger ways to hold companies to account for their promises, many of which never materialize. Of at least $1.1 trillion that private equity firms have invested in the energy sector since 2010, most went toward fossil fuels, according to data from Pitchbook, a company that tracks investment, and an analysis by the Private Equity Stakeholder Project, a nonprofit that pushes for more disclosure about private equity deals.", "Protests planned for Friday and Saturday in Glasgow are expected to draw tens of thousands. A youth-led strike organized by Fridays for Future, the international movement that has grown out of Greta Thunberg\u2019s solo strike in 2018 in Sweden, will see thousands march from Kelvingrove Park to George\u2019s Square."]
